elements.title: STRATEGIC REPORT: Relocation and Acquisition

data.value: AEM increased production capacity by relocating to a newly constructed 35,000 sq. ft. (3,251 m2) facility in Kelowna, British Columbia, adding an extra 10,000 sq. ft. compared to previous premises. The purpose-built facility, announced in 2020 and completed in January 2022, aims to boost operational efficiency with new manufacturing equipment and optimized space.

In September 2021, AEM, via its wholly owned subsidiary, acquired the key avionics division Eagle Audio from Eagle Copters Ltd for CA$4.12m. The deal was internally funded using cash reserves and existing low‐cost debt facilities with HSBC Canada, complementing the company’s product portfolio and ongoing audio R&D initiatives.

Looking ahead, further investments in R&D and sales team expansion are expected. As of 30 June 2022, the Group reported approximately $1.80m cash, a loss of $4.03m, and revenue of $15.70m, alongside increased expenditures in royalty fees, depreciation, R&D, and employee costs.

elements.title: REMUNERATION REPORT (AUDITED) - REMUNERATION POLICY

data.value: The Remuneration Committee of the Board of Directors of Structural Monitoring Systems Plc is responsible for determining and reviewing compensation arrangements for directors and executives.

Executive directors and employees have the opportunity to qualify for participation in the Company Employee Incentive Plan.
Employment agreements are entered into with the Executive Chairman and all other executives, with any options or performance rights lapsing upon completion of the service period.

elements.title: Notes to the financial statements 30 June 2022 - Terms of Performance Rights

data.value: Performance Rights are non-transferable and do not confer rights to attend meetings, vote, receive dividends, or participate in new issues or capital returns.
Performance Rights vest upon satisfaction of the relevant performance hurdle within 3 years from issuance and at the holder's election.
If the performance hurdle is not met or the conversion election is not made within 3 years, the Performance Rights lapse, except as provided in the Plan.
Upon vesting, one ordinary share is issued for each Performance Right upon payment of the par value (£0.0005 per share). Shares will rank equally with existing shares.

In the event of any reconstruction of the issued capital prior to vesting, adjustments may be made to the number of Performance Rights, share prices related to performance hurdles, and any exercise price in accordance with the Plan.

elements.title: Notes to the financial statements - Research and Development

data.value: Research costs are expensed in the period incurred.

Development costs are capitalised when it is probable that the project will be a success, considering commercial and technical feasibility; the entity can use or sell the asset; it has sufficient resources; there is intent to complete the development; and the costs can be reliably measured.

Capitalised development costs are amortised on a straight-line basis over 10 years. Certifications and licence agreement costs are amortised over 5 years; technological intellectual property over 10 years; customer relationships over 5 years; and supplementary type certificates over 10 years.

Goodwill and indefinite-life intangible assets are not amortised but are tested annually for impairment. Other non-financial assets are reviewed for impairment when indicators show the carrying amount may not be recoverable; an impairment loss is recognised if the carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount.
The tax charge is based on the profit for the year using the applicable tax rate, including deferred tax computed using the balance sheet method.

elements.title: Notes to the financial statements & Revenue Recognition Policies

data.value: Recognised together with a corresponding increase in equity over the period in which performance conditions are met, ending at the vesting date. The cumulative expense reflects the proportion of the vesting period expired, with fair value determined at grant date.

Revenue is recognised at a point in time when the repair service is completed and the repaired parts/components are delivered to the customer, meeting control transfer criteria such as payment rights, transfer of possession, risks and rewards, and customer acceptance.

Revenue is recognised at a point in time upon delivery of products (stock or customised parts) when control passes to the customer; pricing is fixed and determinable based on agreed pricing lists. No further performance obligations exist for these sales.

Revenue on shipping for stock parts, customized products, and customer products is recognised when the Group satisfies its performance obligations, typically upon shipment or as the service is provided.
Revenue from contracts to provide services (e.g. prototyping) is recognised over time as services are rendered, or at shipment if a tangible item is delivered.

elements.title: Directors’ Report – Financial and Business Risks

data.value: The Group is exposed to credit risk associated with selling on credit and manages this through credit control procedures (see note 24 in the financial statements).

Liquidity risk arises from the management of working capital. The Group monitors monthly cash inflows and outflows and has an operating loan facility for up to CA$5 million, with CA$0.72m currently available.

Exposure to foreign exchange risk from operations in Canada, USA, and Australia, and transactional currency exposures from sales and purchases in currencies other than the unit's functional currency. This risk increased following the acquisition of a Canadian-based subsidiary, and no hedging strategy is currently in place.
Reliance on one customer that accounts for $7.54 million of revenues out of total revenues of $15.70 million, secured by a licence agreement.
The ongoing impact of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is uncertain, with potential effects on travel, labour movement, and supply chain constraints.
The directors refer to further details on future developments in the Strategic Report (page 6) and note ongoing progress towards the commercialisation of CVM™ technology.
